I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
of  up  to  $120,000,000  equivalent  in  tenge  to  Samruk-Energy  for  the  Restructuring  and 
Transformation Project in Kazakhstan.  
 
2.  The proposed loan will provide long-tenor tenge financing that is not sufficiently available 
in the local market to support Samruk-Energy to increase its balance sheet flexibility by reducing 
foreign  exchange  risk,  improve  operational  efficiency  through  a  corporate  transformation 
program, and identify renewable energy project pipeline.  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
 
3.  Project  identification.  The  Kazakhstan  electricity  sector  is  largely  privatized  and 
unbundled into generation, transmission, and distribution systems, and power traders. In 2016, 
the total installed generation capacity of Kazakhstan was 21.0 gigawatts (GW), with available 
capacity of 18.7 GW. Of the electricity generated, 79.4% was from coal-fired plants, 12.3% was 
from hydropower plants, 7.9% from gas, and 0.4% from solar and wind sources.1 There are 118 
power  plants  with  different  forms  of  ownership,  both  private  and  state  controlled.  The 
government classifies the most important assets as power plants of national importance. While 
some investments have been made, about 70% of installed capacity is considered technically 
obsolete.2 There is still a significant shortage of electricity supply, especially in the southern 
region of Kazakhstan. The entire electricity sector in Kazakhstan needs significant investments 
to rehabilitate the outdated assets and expand the capacity. 3 
 
4.  Samruk-Energy, wholly owned by sovereign wealth fund Samruk-Kazyna, is the largest 
power generation company in Kazakhstan. Samruk-Energy’s generation assets are classified as 
power plants of national importance.4 In 2016, the installed capacity of Samruk-Energy power 
plants totaled 6,804 megawatts (MW) (representing 31% of the total installed capacity of power 
plants in Kazakhstan) and generated 22.5 terawatt-hours (24% of total generation).5 Following 
the Government of Kazakhstan’s Green Economy Concept, in 2015 Samruk-Energy adopted 
the Long-term Development Strategy of Samruk-Energy for 2015–2025.6 Among other things, 
the strategy focuses on the (i) introduction of new technologies at every level of the company,

2  Sector Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
3  According to World Bank 2017 estimates, the power system requires $42 billion of capital investments by 2030. 
The World Bank 2017. Stuck in Transition: Reform Experiences and Challenges Ahead in The Kazakhstan Power

according to Banking Norm No. 147 of the National Bank of Kazakhstan dated 30 May 2016 (clauses 50–54), all 
enterprises of Samruk-Kazyna, including Samruk-Energy, are exempt from any single obligor limits imposed by the 
National Bank of Kazakhstan on commercial banks in Kazakhstan. 
5  This excludes Ust-Kamenogorskaya Hydroelectric Power Plant (331 MW) and Shulbinskaya Hydroelectric Power 
Plant (702 MW), which are under concession to AES Corporation; and Bukhtarminskaya Hydroelectric Power Plant 
(675 MW), which is under concession to Kazzinc. 
6  The government set a target to increase the share of renewable energy in the total generation capacity to 10% by 
2030. Decree of the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan. 2013. Concept of Transition of the Republic of 
Kazakhstan to Green Economy. Astana.

2        
(ii) development of renewable energy (wind and solar) generation from the current 100 MW to 
850 MW by 2025, and (iii) doubling of shareholder value. 
 
5.  However, several macroeconomic challenges have slowed down the implementation of 
Samruk-Energy’s long-term development strategy. In August 2015, because of a steep decline 
in global oil prices, the National Bank of Kazakhstan shifted the nominal exchange rate from a 
fixed to a floating regime. The tenge immediately lost significant value, sliding from T188 = $1 to 
T254 = $1; the depreciation has since continued to T336 = $1 as of 22 October 2017, with the 
currency losing 76% of its value in 26 months. The foreign exchange shock exacerbated the key 
development problem of the electricity sector: the need for a significant amount for the long-term 
financing for the rehabilitation and expansion of the power system. Various Kazakh companies, 
including Samruk-Energy, were negatively affected because of their foreign currency exposure.  
 
6.  The government and Samruk-Energy’s management were swift to respond to the foreign 
exchange shock. In 2015, the government launched the 100 Precise Steps Towards Realization 
of The Five Institutional Reforms, a national plan to modernize the economy.7 As a part of this 
plan, it issued a decree in December 2015 to implement a new privatization program aimed at 
improving the efficiency of state assets and reducing budget expenditures.8 Nine subsidiaries of 
Samruk-Energy were included in the privatization list. In addition, as part of the privatization 
plan, Samruk-Kazyna recruited the Boston Consulting Group to advise on proposed initial public 
offerings (IPOs) of at least seven state-owned enterprises, including Samruk-Energy, by 2020. 
To prepare itself for its IPO, Samruk-Energy prepared and approved a fundamental business 
restructuring and transformation plan to be implemented from 2017 to 2021. The goals are to (i) 
successfully sell its noncore assets to private investors, (ii) add balance sheet flexibility by 
reducing foreign exchange risk, (iii) modify business processes in the remaining businesses, (iv) 
bring the focus back on generation, and (v) become a transparent and efficient power company 
that is attractive for prospective IPO investors. 
 
7.  In  December  2012,  Samruk-Energy  raised  a  5-year  bullet  maturity  $500  million 
eurobond. The rapid depreciation of the tenge has resulted in a significant increase in the debt 
servicing requirement of Samruk-Energy, which uses the tenge as its primary revenue currency. 
This has negatively impacted the company’s balance sheet and stalled the implementation of its 
ongoing  and  planned  projects.  Against this  backdrop,  the  company  approached  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) 
to  support  its  balance sheet  restructuring  plan,  in  particular  its  efforts  to minimize  foreign 
exchange exposure by converting its maturing dollar refinancing requirements into long-term 
tenge-denominated debt. 
 
8.  Project design. Samruk-Energy’s overall business restructuring and transformation plan 
is aimed at the (i) reduction of foreign exchange risks; (ii) improvement of operational efficiency 
of core businesses to maximize shareholder value; and (iii) identification of renewable energy 
opportunities, thereby attracting investors for the IPO.  
9.  The foremost area of transformation is aimed at creating balance sheet flexibility through 
reduction of foreign currency risk by way of refinancing dollar-denominated debt with tenge. The 
company has already secured loans from the EBRD for €100 million equivalent in tenge to 
                                                
7 Kazakhstan Institute for Strategic Studies. 2015. National Plan: 100 Precise Steps Towards Realization of The Five 
Institutional Reforms. Astana. http://kisi.kz/en/pages/national-plan-%E2%80%9C100-precise-steps%E2%80%9D. 
8  Government of Kazakhstan. 2015. Resolution of the Government of the Republic of Kazakhstan as of  30 
December 2015, No. 1141, On Some Privatization Issues for 2016–2020. Astana.

3 
refinance a portion of the $500 million eurobond payment due in December 2017. Given its 
tenge-denominated  revenues,  the  company’s  debt  policy  will  continue  to  be  to  borrow 
predominantly in tenge. Although the rest of the refinancing amount has also been substantially 
secured through lending from local banks, such locally raised debt offers extremely limited 
tenor, thus constraining the company’s financial flexibility. The company would, therefore, prefer 
to seek ADB’s assistance, as it sought the EBRD’s, for longer-tenor facilities, which will allow it 
to enhance its asset–liability profile, and hence facilitate the transformation and restructuring 
initiatives leading toward the planned 2020 IPO. Equity, by way of proceeds from the sale of 
subsidiaries  and  a  small  amount  of  borrowings  from  local  banks,  will  fund  the  remaining 
refinancing and funding requirements for 2017–2021. As the company moves toward restoring 
financial health following the 2015 tenge depreciation, a long-term tenge financing from ADB 
and EBRD, hitherto unavailable from the local market, will support Samruk-Energy to efficiently 
manage its cash flows and diversify its borrowing strategy. 
 
10.  Attaining operational efficiency is the second key objective under the transformation 
process; it is capital-intensive and multidirectional in nature, and relies on four key drivers: (i) 
revenue maximization, (ii) cost reduction, (iii) centralized project management, and (iv) sale of 
non-core assets.  (Confidential information redacted). 
 
11.  In line with the country’s national strategy of decarbonization, which is supported by 
international financial institutions, including ADB, the last area of transformation involves the 
identification of opportunities and completion of the associated prefeasibility studies aimed at 
the  expansion  of  Samruk-Energy’s  renewable  energy  portfolio.    (Confidential  information 
redacted). Without  a  provision  for  long-tenor financing,  this  up-front  work, requiring  longer 
gestation periods, would need to be financed from local sources with shorter duration loans. 
This would adversely impact the financial health and flexibility of the company.9 
 
12.  Borrower. Samruk-Energy was established on 18 April 2007 to develop and implement 
a long-term state policy on the upgrading of existing and the introduction of new generating 
facilities. The founders of the company were Kazakhstan Holding for Management of State 
Assets Samruk and KazTransGaz. As a result of the reorganization through the merger of 
Kazakhstan Holding for Management of State Assets Samruk and Sustainable Development 
Fund  Kazyna,  on  3  November  2008  (which  transferred  KazTransGaz’s  shares  in  Samruk-
Energy  to  the  sovereign  wealth  fund  Samruk-Kazyna),  Samruk-Kazyna  became  the  sole 
shareholder of Samruk-Energy. As of the end of 2016, Samruk-Energy had a total of 22,230 
employees, with female employees accounting for almost 27.5% of its workforce. 
 
13.  Samruk-Energy  is  involved  in  the  generation,  transmission,  distribution,  sale,  and 
purchase of electricity; the mining and sale of coal; and the generation of heat. The company’s 
vertically  integrated  nature  gives  it  greater  control  over  its  supply  chain  and  distribution 
channels. A breakdown of its income by segment in 2016 is as follows: electricity generation 
(48%), distribution and sale of electricity (38%), coal production (13%), and other lines of 
business (1%).10 Samruk-Energy is also the largest power generation company in Kazakhstan. 
As of 31 December 2016, the aggregate installed power generation capacity of Samruk-Energy 
was 6,804 MW. In FY2016, Samruk-Energy generated 22.5 terawatt-hours of electricity, which 
                                                
9  Infrastructure investments in renewable energy projects are not a component of the proposed project. Financing for 
those projects will be sought by Samruk-Energy separately, after the pipeline of the renewable energy projects is 
identified and feasibility studies are completed. 
10 Samruk-Energy. 2017. Integrated Annual Report 2016. Astana.

4        
represents  approximately  24%  of  the  total  electricity  generated  in  Kazakhstan  during  that 
period. Samruk-Energy has 25 subsidiaries, including two hydropower plants, two wind power 
plants, one solar power plant, four thermal power plants (including combined heat and power 
plants), five power distribution and transmission companies, and several other assets related to 
exploration and production. The privatization plan set by the government envisages the sale of 
all combined heat and power plants, distribution companies, and all other noncore assets. The 
company’s strategy is to focus on power generation and dispose businesses (distribution and 
heat and power sales) where tariff adjustments are more delicate because of social sensitivities. 
Sales of these assets are expected to be completed by 2020. 
 
14.  Samruk-Energy’s  revenue  decreased  by  18%  from  T221  billion  ($1,213  million)  in 
FY2014  to  T184  billion  ($541  million)  in  FY2015,  with  earnings  before  interest,  taxes, 
depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) decreasing from T135 billion ($742 million) in FY2014 
to T80 billion ($236 million) in FY2015, and the company recording a net loss of T77 billion 
($228 million) in FY2015 compared with a net profit of T13 billion ($73 million) in FY2014. The 
deterioration in Samruk-Energy’s financial results was caused by (i) a significant decline in 
demand for electricity because of slowing economic activity, and (ii) foreign exchange loss 
because of the dollar-denominated borrowings, which accounted for approximately 60% of the 
total borrowing as of the end of FY2015. Profitability, however, stabilized in FY2016, as the 
company recorded an EBITDA of T75 billion ($227 million), and net profit of T18 billion ($55 
million), although turnover declined slightly to T181 billion ($544 million) during the year. In 
FY2016, Samruk-Energy had total assets of T1,049 billion ($3,148 million), total liabilities of 
T532 billion ($1,598 million), and a net worth of T517 billion ($1,550 million). 
 
15.  Integrity due diligence was conducted. No significant integrity risks were identified. 11 
ADB’s review of the entity does not give ADB cause to believe that such entity has been 
established, or is being used for money laundering, or terrorism financing in the jurisdictions 
involved in the project. Tax integrity due diligence was not required.12 
 
B.  Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
16.  Impact. The project is aligned with the following impact: attainment of a competitive 
electricity generation sector that supports the country’s economic growth by 2023. 
 
17.  Outcome. The project will have the following outcome: improved financial flexibility and 
operational efficiency and competitiveness of Samruk-Energy. 
 
18.  Outputs.  Specific  outputs  of  the  project  will  be  (i)  achievement  of  balance  sheet 
flexibility,  (ii)  completion  of  Samruk-Energy’s  corporate  transformation  program,  and  (iii) 
identification of a renewable energy project pipeline.13

C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
19.  Consistency with ADB strategy and country strategy. The project is consistent with 
ADB’s Midterm Review of Strategy 2020, which identifies environment and climate change and 
infrastructure development as two of the four strategic priorities to sharpen the focus of ADB 
operations.14 ADB’s support for the project is in line with its country partnership strategy for 
Kazakhstan, 2017–2021 and its country operations business plan for Kazakhstan, 2018–2020,15 
which focus on energy sector and private sector development. The project is also in line with the 
strategy of the government to reduce its carbon footprint.16  
 
20.  Consistency with sector strategy and relevant ADB operations. The project is also 
consistent  with  ADB’s  Energy  Policy,  which  emphasizes  investments  in  energy  efficiency, 
renewable  energy  projects,  private  sector  participation,  wider  access  to  energy,  and 
enhancement of the viability of the energy sector.17

G.  Unique Features 
 
24.  The  project  will  be  ADB’s  first-ever  nonsovereign  transaction  with  a  state-owned 
enterprise  in  Kazakhstan.  Enhancing  the  financial  flexibility  and  supporting  efficiency 
improvements in a state-owned enterprise that has a strong presence in the power sector would 
have a cascading effect on the economy of Kazakhstan, by way of reducing overall power 
prices in the long term. This project is also the first nonsovereign transaction being jointly 
processed by ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) and Central and West Asia 
Department  (CWRD).  The  project  provides  a  strong  opportunity  for  PSOD  and  CWRD  to 
leverage their respective areas of expertise. CWRD’s sector-level engagement, policy dialogue, 
and  technical  assistance  (TA)  being  provided  to  Samruk-Energy  have  led  to  the  project’s 
origination and due diligence.18 PSOD is primarily responsible for the financial structuring of the 
transaction and commercial due diligence. Lessons learned from this joint engagement will form 
possible future approaches to joint project preparation by PSOD and ADB regional departments.

III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
25.  The proposed ADB assistance comprises an unsecured corporate finance loan of up to 
$120 million equivalent in tenge with a maximum tenor of 7 years. In line with Samruk-Energy’s 
needs and ADB’s ability to raise funding from the local market, the loan may be split into 
tranches with multiple repayment dates.  
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
26.  ADB is already supporting Kazakhstan’s energy sector to achieve its intended nationally 
determined contribution (footnote 16) and renewable power generation targets (footnote 7). In 
particular, ADB’s assistance supported the preparation and design of a framework for auctions 
of  renewable  energy  projects.  Two  other  ongoing  TA  projects  are  supporting  the  system 
operator to plan generation and transmission systems and install modernized control techniques 
to address renewable energy intermittency.19 These activities are expected to spur investments 
in the electricity sector, which needs billions of dollars to rehabilitate and expand (footnote 4). 
The  proposed  project  contributes  to  the  same  goal  of  making  necessary  investments  by 
providing long-term tenge financing, which is currently insufficient in Kazakhstan. Balance sheet 
flexibility through the reduction of foreign currency risk by refinancing dollar-denominated debt 
with long-term tenge financing will free up resources for Samruk-Energy for future development 
and  preparations  for  the  upcoming  IPO.  ADB’s  assistance  will  enable  Samruk-Energy  to 
undertake capital expenditures with long payback periods through efficiency measures and 
initiate the identification of a renewable projects pipeline.  
 
27.  In  addition,  the  benefits  from  the  reduction  of  Samruk-Energy’s  dollar-denominated 
borrowing will be channeled to end customers by partially protecting them from electricity tariff 
escalations  caused  by  future  foreign  exchange  devaluations.  Furthermore,  improved 
competitiveness  and  the  reduced  cost  of  electricity  of  Samruk-Energy—the  largest  power 
generation company in Kazakhstan—will provide economic benefits to the entire economy.20

process. International and national corporate restructuring and financial modeling experts will 
provide  advisory  services  to  the  company  in  business  transformation  and  balance  sheet 
restructuring. Environmental and social safeguards experts, also recruited under the TA, will

IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
30.  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project is classified as 
category  C  for  environment,  category  C  for  involuntary  resettlement,  and  category  C  for 
indigenous peoples. The potential environmental and social impacts of the project have been 
identified, and effective measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for the adverse 
impacts are incorporated in the safeguard reports and plans. A corporate audit of Samruk-
Energy was undertaken by an external third party in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement requirements for general corporate finance. 21 The audit found that the institutional 
capacity and commitment of Samruk-Energy to manage its social and environmental impacts 
are deemed satisfactory to meet local and national requirements, but corporate-level capacity 
development is needed to ensure that the existing ESMS is strengthened and implemented in 
accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. Samruk-Energy has committed to the 
development of an ESMS that is acceptable to ADB prior to first disbursement.22 
 
31.  Samruk-Energy  will  comply  with  national  labor  laws  and,  pursuant  to  ADB’s  Social 
Protection Strategy (2001), will take measures to comply with the internationally recognized 
core labor standards.23 The borrower will report regularly to ADB on (i) its compliance with such 
laws,  and  (ii)  the  measures  taken.  Information  disclosure  and  consultation  with  relevant 
stakeholders will be conducted in accordance with ADB requirements.24 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
32.  Samruk-Energy was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice 
relating to combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will 
ensure  that  the  investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting 
corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism, and remedies for ADB in the event 
of noncompliance. 
 
C.  Investment Limitations 
 
33.  The  proposed  loan  is  within  the  medium-term,  country,  industry,  group,  and  single 
exposure limits for nonsovereign investments.

D.  Assurances 
 
34.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (the 
Charter), 25  ADB  will  proceed  with  the  proposed  assistance  upon  establishing  that  the 
Government of Kazakhstan has no objection to the proposed assistance to Samruk-Energy. 
ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, 
following approval of the proposed assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
35.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
$120,000,000 equivalent in tenge to Samruk-Energy for the Restructuring and Transformation 
Project in Kazakhstan, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with 
those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board.
